page.title: 08Hill Farming, Kinbrace
page.content: The sheep which graze on our hills are a small hardy breed known as North Country Cheviots. Winter is very severe in the hills and the young ewe hogs(last year's lambs) are taken to the lowland farms to be wintered. The older sheep are fed with hay and vitamin blocks during the bad weather. Soon the lambing starts. Shepherds have to attend the lambs from early morning until late at night.Then the dipping and clipping of the sheep begins.First they have to be gathered and taken to the clipping sheds. Later in the year the hay is cut and baled for the winter and the sheep sales begin. The sheep sale at Lairg is one of the biggest sheep sales in Britain. Many of the sheep are bought by buyers from the south. The year passes and soon it is time for the hogs to be wintered.
